# 🎉 Your Personalized Music Lesson Plan

---

## Lesson Overview

- **Grade Level**: Elementary (Grades 2–4)  
- **Duration**: 45 minutes  
- **Focus Area**: Create Strand — Composing and improvising original musical ideas  
- **Primary Standard**: Custom Lesson — Students will create short musical compositions using rhythm, melody, and form through collaborative and individual exploration.  
- **Learning Objectives**:  
  - Students will compose a 4-beat rhythmic pattern using body percussion and classroom instruments.  
  - Students will improvise a 4-note melodic motif using solfege (Do, Re, Mi) or xylophone bars.  
  - Students will combine their rhythm and melody into a short 8-beat musical phrase and perform it for peers.  
  - Students will reflect on their creative process using verbal or visual self-assessment.

---

## Learning Objectives

By the end of this lesson, students will be able to:  
1. **Create** a rhythmic pattern using quarter notes and eighth notes (or ta and ti-ti) with body percussion or instruments.  
2. **Improvise** a melodic motif using three pitches (Do, Re, Mi) on a pitched instrument or voice.  
3. **Combine** rhythm and melody into an 8-beat phrase and perform it with confidence.  
4. **Reflect** on their composition using a simple self-assessment rubric or emoji scale.

---

## Materials and Resources

### Required Materials:
- Classroom percussion instruments (tambourines, rhythm sticks, hand drums, triangles, sandblocks)  
- Orff instruments (xylophones, metallophones, glockenspiels — at least 1 per 3 students)  
- Whiteboard or chart paper with rhythmic notation (ta, ti-ti) and solfege (Do, Re, Mi)  
- Visual aids: “Rhythm Recipe Cards” (pre-printed 4-beat patterns using ta/ti-ti)  
- “Melody Builder Cards” (pre-printed 4-note motifs using Do-Re-Mi)  
- Student reflection sheets (with emoji scale or simple checklist)  
- Timer or classroom clock  
- Optional: Digital audio recorder or phone for recording performances  

### Setup Requirements:
- Arrange instruments in accessible stations around the room.  
- Post large visual aids at front of room.  
- Prepare 1–2 “Composer Stations” with xylophones and rhythm instruments for small groups.  
- Ensure students are seated in a semi-circle or in small groups for easy transition to stations.

---

## Lesson Procedure

### Introduction/Hook (7 minutes)

**Activity: “Rhythm Detective” Warm-Up**  
- Teacher claps a 4-beat rhythm using ta and ti-ti (e.g., “ta ti-ti ta”).  
- Students echo the rhythm using body percussion (clap, stomp, snap).  
- Repeat with 2–3 variations.  
- Ask: “What did you notice about the beats? How many strong beats? Where did the fast notes go?”  
- Introduce today’s goal: “Today, YOU are the composer — you’ll create your own rhythm AND melody to share with the class!”

**Connection to Prior Learning**:  
- Review prior knowledge: “Remember when we learned ta = quarter note and ti-ti = two eighth notes?”  
- Briefly demonstrate solfege: “Do, Re, Mi — these are the notes we’ll use to build our melody.”

---

### Main Activities (30 minutes)

#### Activity 1: Rhythm Creation Station (10 minutes)

**Instructions**:  
- Divide class into 3–4 small groups.  
- Each group receives a “Rhythm Recipe Card” with a 4-beat pattern (e.g., “ta ta ti-ti ta” or “ti-ti ta ta ti-ti”).  
- Students choose 1–2 classroom instruments to perform their rhythm.  
- Teacher circulates, modeling how to keep steady beat and encouraging creativity (e.g., “Can you add a drum accent on beat 3?”).  
- Groups practice 2x before sharing.

**Differentiation Tip**:  
- Struggling learners: Provide cards with only ta (quarter notes).  
- Advanced learners: Challenge them to add rests or syncopation.

#### Activity 2: Melody Improvisation Station (10 minutes)

**Instructions**:  
- Groups rotate to “Melody Builder” station with xylophones or metallophones tuned to Do, Re, Mi.  
- Students draw a “Melody Builder Card” (e.g., “Start on Do, end on Mi, use Re once”).  
- Students improvise a 4-note melody using only Do, Re, Mi.  
- Teacher models: “I’ll play Do-Re-Mi-Do — now you try!”  
- Encourage students to sing their melody first, then play it.

**Differentiation Tip**:  
- Struggling learners: Use color-coded bars or stickers to identify Do, Re, Mi.  
- Advanced learners: Add a fifth note (Fa) or create a 6-note motif.

#### Activity 3: Combine & Perform (10 minutes)

**Instructions**:  
- Groups combine their 4-beat rhythm and 4-note melody into an 8-beat phrase.  
- Example: Rhythm = “ta ti-ti ta ta” | Melody = “Do Re Mi Do”  
- Students decide how to perform: one student plays rhythm, another melody, or combine on one instrument.  
- Each group performs for the class (30 seconds each).  
- Class gives “Thumbs Up” feedback for creativity and steady beat.

**Teacher Modeling**:  
- Perform a sample 8-beat phrase: “Clap ta ti-ti ta ta, then play Do-Re-Mi-Do on xylophone.”  
- Emphasize: “It doesn’t have to be perfect — it has to be YOURS!”

---

### Closure/Reflection (8 minutes)

**Activity: “Composer’s Corner” Reflection**  
- Students complete a simple reflection sheet:  
  - “I created a rhythm using: ___”  
  - “My melody started on ___ and ended on ___”  
  - “I felt ___ about my composition (😊 😐 😞)”  
  - “One thing I liked about my music was ___”  
- Volunteers share reflections aloud.  
- Teacher summarizes: “Today you were composers! You created rhythm, melody, and put them together — that’s how music is made!”

**Connection to Future Learning**:  
- “Next week, we’ll add dynamics and form to make our compositions even more expressive!”

---

## Assessment Strategies

### Formative Assessment:
- **Observation Checklist**:  
  - ✅ Creates a 4-beat rhythm using ta/ti-ti  
  - ✅ Improvises a 4-note melody using Do-Re-Mi  
  - ✅ Combines rhythm and melody into 8-beat phrase  
  - ✅ Performs with steady beat and confidence  

- **Peer Feedback**: Students give “Thumbs Up” for creativity, steady beat, and clear performance.

### Success Criteria Rubric (for teacher use):

| Criteria                  | Exceeds (4)             | Meets (3)               | Approaching (2)         | Not Yet (1)             |
|---------------------------|--------------------------|--------------------------|--------------------------|--------------------------|
| Rhythm Creation           | Complex pattern, steady beat | Simple pattern, steady beat | Inconsistent beat       | No clear pattern         |
| Melody Improvisation      | Creative use of 3+ notes | Uses Do-Re-Mi accurately | Limited note choice     | No melody created        |
| Performance               | Confident, clear, expressive | Steady, audible         | Hesitant, quiet         | Did not perform          |
| Reflection                | Detailed, thoughtful     | Basic self-assessment   | Minimal response        | No reflection            |

---

## Differentiation

### For Struggling Learners:
- Provide rhythm cards with only quarter notes (ta).  
- Use color-coded xylophone bars or visual pitch charts.  
- Pair with a peer buddy for collaborative creation.  
- Allow verbal or pictorial reflection instead of written.

### For Advanced Learners:
- Challenge to add syncopation, rests, or dynamics (loud/soft).  
- Introduce Fa or So to expand melody.  
- Invite to compose a 12-beat phrase or add a partner’s part.  
- Encourage them to lead a small group or record their composition.

### For English Language Learners:
- Use visual rhythm and solfege cards with icons.  
- Pair with bilingual peers or use translation apps for instructions.  
- Allow responses in native language or through drawing.

### For Students with Physical Disabilities:
- Provide adaptive instruments (e.g., drum with beater strap, mallets with grip aids).  
- Allow use of voice or digital apps (e.g., Chrome Music Lab) if physical instruments are challenging.

---

## Reflection and Extension

### Student Reflection Questions:
1. What was the most fun part of creating your music?  
2. What would you change if you made this again?  
3. How did working with your group help you create something new?

### Extension Activities:
- **Homework**: Draw your 8-beat phrase using rhythm symbols and solfege.  
- **Cross-Curricular Connection**: Write a short story that matches your music’s mood (e.g., “My rhythm is a running rabbit!”).  
- **Tech Integration**: Use Chrome Music Lab’s Song Maker to recreate your composition digitally [Web Source: https://musiclab.chromeexperiments.com/Song-Maker/].  
- **Performance Extension**: Combine all group phrases into a class “Rhythm & Melody Medley” for school assembly.

---

## Citations

[Web Source: https://musiclab.chromeexperiments.com/Song-Maker/] — Chrome Music Lab: Song Maker (Google, 2024). Free online tool for composing melodies and rhythms using visual interface. Accessed April 2024.

[Web Source: https://www.nafme.org/standards] — National Association for Music Education (NAFME). National Core Arts Standards for Music. Accessed April 2024.

[Web Source: https://www.teachervision.com/lesson-plans/music-lesson-plans] — TeacherVision. “Elementary Music Lesson Plans.” Accessed April 2024.

[Web Source: https://www.musiceducators.org/standards] — National Standards for Music Education. Music Educators National Conference (MENC). Accessed April 2024.

---

*Note: All activities are aligned with NC Music Standards for Elementary Create Strand and are designed for maximum engagement, creativity, and accessibility. Lesson can be adapted for virtual or hybrid settings using digital tools and breakout rooms.*

---

# 🎉 Your Personalized Music Lesson Plan

---

## Lesson Overview

**Grade Level**: Middle School (Grades 6–8)  
**Duration**: 45 minutes  
**Focus Area**: Create Strand — Composing and improvising original musical ideas  
**Primary Standard**: Custom Lesson — Students will compose a short rhythmic and melodic phrase using classroom instruments, demonstrating understanding of musical structure, repetition, and contrast.  
**Learning Objectives**:  
- Students will create an original 4-beat rhythmic pattern using body percussion or unpitched percussion instruments.  
- Students will compose a 4-beat melodic phrase using a pentatonic scale on pitched instruments (e.g., xylophones, glockenspiels, or boomwhackers).  
- Students will combine their rhythmic and melodic phrases into a cohesive 8-beat musical idea and perform it for peers.  
- Students will reflect on their creative process and provide constructive feedback to peers.

---

## Learning Objectives

By the end of this lesson, students will be able to:  
1. **Compose** a 4-beat rhythmic pattern using quarter notes, eighth notes, and rests.  
2. **Improvise** a 4-beat melodic phrase using the C pentatonic scale (C–D–E–G–A).  
3. **Combine** rhythmic and melodic elements into a unified 8-beat musical phrase.  
4. **Perform** their composition with appropriate dynamics and articulation.  
5. **Evaluate** peer compositions using a simple rubric focused on creativity, structure, and expression.

---

## Materials and Resources

### Required Materials:
- Classroom percussion instruments (e.g., rhythm sticks, tambourines, hand drums, cowbells)  
- Pitched instruments: xylophones, glockenspiels, or boomwhackers tuned to C pentatonic scale  
- Whiteboard or chart paper with staff notation and rhythm notation  
- Student composition worksheets (optional)  
- Metronome or digital beat app (e.g., “Metronome Beats” or “Pro Metronome” [Web Source: https://apps.apple.com/us/app/metronome-beats/id1452302484])  
- Projector or screen for visual rhythm/melody examples (optional)  

### Setup Requirements:
- Arrange instruments in accessible stations around the room  
- Create small group workspaces (4–5 students per group)  
- Prepare a sample 8-beat composition to model (e.g., rhythmic pattern: “ta ta ti-ti ta” + melodic pattern: “C D E C”)  
- Post learning objectives and success criteria visibly  

---

## Lesson Procedure

### Introduction/Hook (5–7 minutes)

**Engaging Opening**:  
- Begin with a “Call and Response” rhythm game using body percussion. Teacher claps a 4-beat rhythm; students echo. Gradually increase complexity.  
- Ask: *“What makes a rhythm memorable? What makes a melody stick in your head?”*  
- Introduce the lesson: *“Today, you’re going to be composers! You’ll create your own 8-beat musical phrase using rhythm and melody — just like songwriters do!”*

**Connection to Prior Learning**:  
- Briefly review:  
  - Rhythm values: quarter note = 1 beat, eighth note = ½ beat, rest = silence  
  - C pentatonic scale: C–D–E–G–A (no sharps/flats — easy to improvise with)  
- Show a simple 4-beat rhythm and melody example on the board. Clap/sing it together.

---

### Main Activities (30 minutes)

#### Activity 1: Rhythmic Composition (8 minutes)  
- Students work in pairs or small groups.  
- Each group creates a 4-beat rhythmic pattern using:  
  - At least 1 quarter note  
  - At least 1 eighth note pair  
  - At least 1 rest  
- Encourage experimentation with dynamics (loud/soft) and articulation (staccato/legato).  
- Groups practice performing their rhythm with body percussion or unpitched instruments.  
- **Teacher Tip**: Walk around and provide feedback: *“Try adding a rest to create space!”* or *“Can you make that rhythm bouncy?”*

#### Activity 2: Melodic Composition (8 minutes)  
- Students switch to pitched instruments (xylophones, boomwhackers, etc.).  
- Using only the C pentatonic scale, students create a 4-beat melodic phrase.  
- Suggest starting/ending on C for stability.  
- Encourage repetition or contrast (e.g., same rhythm but different notes, or same notes with different rhythm).  
- Groups practice playing their melody slowly, then with the metronome set to 80–100 BPM.

#### Activity 3: Combining Rhythm + Melody (8 minutes)  
- Groups combine their 4-beat rhythm and 4-beat melody into one 8-beat phrase.  
- Structure: Rhythm first (beats 1–4), then melody (beats 5–8).  
- Encourage students to add a dynamic shape (e.g., crescendo or decrescendo) or a fermata at the end.  
- Practice as a group, ensuring everyone plays their part together.

#### Activity 4: Peer Performance & Feedback (6 minutes)  
- Each group performs their 8-beat composition for the class.  
- After each performance, the class gives “Two Stars and a Wish” feedback:  
  - Two things they liked (e.g., “I liked the syncopation!”)  
  - One thing to try next time (e.g., “Try adding a rest in the melody.”)  
- Teacher models feedback first.

---

### Closure/Reflection (5–8 minutes)

**Summary**:  
- Recap: *“Today we composed rhythms, melodies, and combined them into a musical phrase. You used repetition, contrast, and dynamics — just like real composers!”*

**Student Reflection**:  
- Students answer 1–2 of the following in writing or verbally:  
  - *What was the most challenging part of composing?*  
  - *What did you learn about combining rhythm and melody?*  
  - *How did your group work together?*

**Connection to Future Learning**:  
- *“Next week, we’ll add harmony to our compositions using ostinatos — stay tuned!”*

---

## Assessment Strategies

### Formative Assessment:
- **Observation**: Teacher circulates during composition time, noting:  
  - Use of correct rhythm values  
  - Melodic use of pentatonic scale  
  - Group collaboration and problem-solving  
- **Peer Feedback**: “Two Stars and a Wish” provides immediate, student-centered assessment.  
- **Performance Checklist** (for teacher use):  
  - ✅ Rhythm includes quarter, eighth, and rest  
  - ✅ Melody uses only C pentatonic notes  
  - ✅ Phrase is 8 beats total  
  - ✅ Group performs together with dynamics/articulation  

### Success Criteria Rubric (Simplified for Middle School):

| Criteria                 | Exceeds Expectations | Meets Expectations | Needs Improvement |
|--------------------------|----------------------|--------------------|-------------------|
| Rhythm Accuracy          | Uses 3+ note values creatively | Uses required values correctly | Missing required elements |
| Melody Creativity        | Inventive, clear structure | Uses pentatonic scale appropriately | Limited note choices or errors |
| Performance Unity        | Group plays together with expression | Group plays together | Timing or coordination issues |
| Peer Feedback Engagement | Gives specific, helpful feedback | Gives basic feedback | Minimal or no feedback |

---

## Differentiation

### For Advanced Students:
- Challenge to add harmony (e.g., a simple ostinato on a drone note like C).  
- Encourage syncopation or mixed meter (e.g., 3+5 beats instead of 4+4).  
- Invite them to notate their composition using standard notation or graphic notation.

### For Struggling Students:
- Provide pre-made rhythm/melody cards to choose from and combine.  
- Allow use of a single instrument or body percussion only.  
- Pair with a peer mentor for collaborative composition.  
- Offer visual aids: rhythm icons, color-coded notes, or a “composition template” worksheet.

### For English Language Learners (ELL) or Students with IEPs:
- Use visual aids and modeling extensively.  
- Provide sentence stems for peer feedback: *“I liked how you…”*  
- Allow verbal or pictorial responses for reflection.  
- Offer extended time or small group support during composition phase.

---

## Reflection and Extension

### Student Reflection Questions:
1. What part of composing did you enjoy the most? Why?  
2. How did working in a group help or challenge your creativity?  
3. If you had more time, what would you change or add to your composition?

### Extension Activities:
- **Homework**: Record your 8-beat phrase using a phone or tablet and share via Google Classroom.  
- **Cross-Curricular Connection**: Write a short poem or story that matches the mood of your composition.  
- **Tech Integration**: Use free apps like Soundtrap or Chrome Music Lab to record and layer compositions [Web Source: https://musiclab.chromeexperiments.com/].  
- **Performance Extension**: Combine all group compositions into a class “Rhythm & Melody Medley” for a school assembly or parent night.

---

## Citations

[1] North Carolina Department of Public Instruction. “Music Standard Course of Study.” https://www.dpi.nc.gov/curriculum/music  
[2] “Metronome Beats — iOS App.” Apple App Store, https://apps.apple.com/us/app/metronome-beats/id1452302484  
[3] Chrome Music Lab. “Experiments in Music and Technology.” Google, https://musiclab.chromeexperiments.com/  
[4] National Association for Music Education (NAfME). “Creating in the Music Classroom.” https://nafme.org/creating-in-the-music-classroom/  

---

# 🎉 Your Personalized Music Lesson Plan

---

## Lesson Overview

- **Grade Level**: Elementary (Grades 2–4)  
- **Duration**: 45 minutes  
- **Focus Area**: Create Strand — Students will compose and perform original rhythmic patterns using body percussion and classroom instruments.  
- **Primary Standard**: Custom Lesson — “Students will create and express original rhythmic compositions using body percussion and classroom instruments.”  
- **Learning Objectives**:  
  - Students will identify and perform basic rhythmic patterns (quarter notes, eighth notes, rests).  
  - Students will collaboratively compose a 4-beat rhythmic pattern using body percussion.  
  - Students will transfer their composed pattern to classroom instruments and perform it for peers.  
  - Students will reflect on their creative process and evaluate peer compositions using a simple rubric.

---

## Learning Objectives

By the end of this lesson, students will be able to:

1. **Perform** a 4-beat rhythmic pattern using body percussion (clap, snap, stomp, pat) with accurate timing and dynamics.  
2. **Compose** an original 4-beat rhythmic pattern using quarter notes, eighth notes, and rests.  
3. **Transfer** their composition to classroom instruments (e.g., tambourines, rhythm sticks, hand drums) and perform it with ensemble awareness.  
4. **Reflect** on their creative process and provide constructive feedback to peers using a visual rubric.

---

## Materials and Resources

### Required Materials:
- Classroom percussion instruments (tambourines, rhythm sticks, hand drums, shakers, cowbells — 1 per 2 students)  
- Visual rhythm cards (quarter note, eighth note, rest)  
- Whiteboard or chart paper with large staff and beat boxes  
- Student “Rhythm Composer” worksheets (with 4-beat grids)  
- Optional: Digital metronome app or classroom metronome  
- Sticky notes or colored cards for peer feedback

### Setup Requirements:
- Arrange desks/tables in small groups of 4–5 students for collaborative work.  
- Place instruments in accessible bins at each group station.  
- Post rhythm symbol visuals at the front of the room.  
- Prepare 1 “Rhythm Composer” worksheet per student.  
- Set up a “performance circle” area for sharing compositions.

### Preparation Notes:
- Pre-load a simple 4-beat rhythm pattern on the whiteboard for modeling.  
- Test all instruments for functionality.  
- Print and laminate rhythm cards for reuse.  
- Prepare a visual rubric poster: “My Rhythm Was… 1=Needs Work, 2=Good, 3=Awesome!” with icons for rhythm accuracy, creativity, and teamwork.

---

## Lesson Procedure

### Introduction/Hook (5–10 minutes)

**Activity: “Rhythm Detective” Warm-Up**  
- Teacher claps a 4-beat pattern using quarter notes and rests (e.g., “clap-rest-clap-clap”).  
- Students echo the pattern using body percussion.  
- Teacher gradually adds eighth notes (“clap-clap-rest-clap”) and asks students to identify the “fast” notes.  
- Students practice “calling out” the rhythm using “ta” for quarter notes and “ti-ti” for eighth notes.  
- **Connection to Prior Learning**: “Remember when we learned ‘ta’ and ‘ti-ti’? Today, you’re going to be composers — you’ll make your own patterns!”

> *Time Allocation*: 8 minutes

---

### Main Activities (25–35 minutes)

#### Activity 1: Collaborative Composition (10 minutes)  
- Students work in groups of 4–5.  
- Each group receives 1 “Rhythm Composer” worksheet with 4 empty beat boxes.  
- Teacher models: “I’m going to make a 4-beat pattern: ta-rest-ti-ti-ta.”  
- Groups create their own 4-beat pattern using quarter notes, eighth notes, and rests.  
- Students practice performing their pattern using body percussion (clap, stomp, snap).  
- Teacher circulates, prompting: “Is your pattern 4 beats? Can you say it using ‘ta’ and ‘ti-ti’?”

#### Activity 2: Instrument Transfer & Rehearsal (10 minutes)  
- Groups choose 1–2 instruments to represent their pattern (e.g., drum for “ta,” shaker for “ti-ti”).  
- Students rehearse their pattern with instruments, focusing on staying together.  
- Teacher provides feedback: “Are you all starting together? Is the tempo steady?”  
- Groups practice performing their pattern 3 times with a steady beat (use metronome if available).

#### Activity 3: Performance Circle (5 minutes)  
- Each group performs their composition in the “performance circle.”  
- Audience students follow along by tapping the beat on their knees.  
- After each performance, audience gives feedback using sticky notes: “I liked how you used ___!” or “Try adding ___ next time!”

> *Time Allocation*: 25 minutes total (10 + 10 + 5)

---

### Closure/Reflection (5–10 minutes)

**Activity: “Rhythm Reflection”**  
- Students return to seats and complete a 3-question reflection on their worksheet:  
  1. “What was your favorite part of creating your rhythm?”  
  2. “What was one thing you learned about working with your group?”  
  3. “If you could change one thing about your rhythm, what would it be?”  
- Teacher invites 2–3 volunteers to share responses.  
- **Connection to Future Learning**: “Next week, we’ll add melody to your rhythms — imagine your rhythm with a tune!”

> *Time Allocation*: 7 minutes

---

## Assessment Strategies

### Formative Assessment:
- **Teacher Observation Checklist**:  
  - [ ] Student can identify and perform quarter/eighth notes and rests  
  - [ ] Student contributes to group composition  
  - [ ] Student transfers pattern accurately to instrument  
  - [ ] Student performs with steady beat and ensemble awareness  

- **Peer Feedback Rubric**:  
  Students use a visual 3-point scale to rate peer performances:  
  - **Rhythm Accuracy** (Did it match the pattern?)  
  - **Creativity** (Did it include interesting rhythms?)  
  - **Teamwork** (Did everyone participate and stay together?)

### Success Criteria:
- Students create and perform a 4-beat pattern with at least 2 different note values (e.g., quarter + eighth).  
- Students demonstrate ensemble awareness (starting/stopping together, steady tempo).  
- Students provide at least 1 specific piece of feedback to a peer.

---

## Differentiation

### For Advanced Learners:
- Challenge students to add dynamics (loud/soft) or a 2-measure pattern.  
- Allow them to create a “call-and-response” pattern with another group.  
- Invite them to lead their group’s rehearsal or teach the pattern to another group.

### For Struggling Learners:
- Provide pre-made rhythm cards to arrange into patterns.  
- Pair with a peer buddy for collaborative composition.  
- Use color-coded rhythm symbols (red = quarter, blue = eighth, green = rest).  
- Allow use of a “beat keeper” (metronome or teacher’s steady clapping) during performance.

### For ELL/Students with IEPs:
- Use visual rhythm icons and gestures (e.g., hand motions for “ta” and “ti-ti”).  
- Provide sentence starters for reflection: “My favorite part was ___ because ___.”  
- Allow verbal or drawn responses instead of written reflection.

---

## Reflection and Extension

### Student Reflection Questions:
1. “What did you learn about creating music with others?”  
2. “How did your group solve problems when your rhythm didn’t sound right?”  
3. “What rhythm symbol did you use the most? Why?”

### Extension Activities:
- **Homework**: “Create a 4-beat rhythm at home using kitchen utensils. Record or draw it to share next class.”  
- **Cross-Curricular Connection**: Math — Students count beats and fractions (e.g., “A quarter note = 1 beat, an eighth note = ½ beat”).  
- **Art Integration**: Students draw a “rhythm monster” that represents their pattern using shapes for notes and rests.  
- **Technology Extension**: Use free apps like *Chrome Music Lab*’s Rhythm Maker to recreate their pattern digitally [Web Source: https://musiclab.chromeexperiments.com/Rhythm/].

---

1. National Association for Music Education (NAfME). “Creating in Music Education.” https://nafme.org/creating-in-music-education/  
2. Chrome Music Lab. “Rhythm Maker.” https://musiclab.chromeexperiments.com/Rhythm/ [Web Source: https://musiclab.chromeexperiments.com/Rhythm/]  
3. North Carolina Department of Public Instruction. “K–12 Music Standards.” https://www.dpi.nc.gov/standards-and-instruction/academic-standards/music-standards [Web Source: https://www.dpi.nc.gov/standards-and-instruction/academic-standards/music-standards]  
4. Teaching Rhythm: A Practical Guide for Elementary Music Teachers. “Body Percussion and Rhythm Composition.” https://www.teachermusic.com/body-percussion-lesson-plans/ [Web Source: https://www.teachermusic.com/body-percussion-lesson-plans/]
